articles.name: Protect - User Guide (COM Add-In)
articles.title: Protect - User Guide (COM Add-In)
articles.body:
Protect is encryption software that allows you to control and protect the information and data that you send. Protect integrates seamlessly into your Microsoft Outlook account. If Microsoft Outlook is not available, you can use Protect functionality using Web Access.

Note:The information in this guide is the default configuration of Protect. Your experience may vary depending on your organization’s configuration choices.

Encryption

Protect integrates with your Microsoft Outlook and allows you to control and protect the information and data that you send.

When composing a new email, an Unclassified button is displayed. This allows you to select the appropriate level of email security for the email you compose.

When selecting the Unclassified button, the following encryption options are available by default:

Large File Transfer

When composing a new email, an Attach Large Files button is displayed. Selecting Attach Large Files opens a side panel. Here, you can drag and drop or browse and select files to attach.

Note:

  • By default, files greater than 10MB will be attached using LFT (this threshold is customizable and may be greater than 10MB). The side panel opens automatically to display the attachments.
  • The recommended maximum file size for large file transfer is 2GB.

articles.name: Protect - User Guide (Web Add-In)
articles.title: Protect - User Guide (Web Add-In)
articles.body:
Protect integrates with Microsoft Outlook, allowing you to control and protect the information you send seamlessly. Protect allows you to Encrypt emails and transfer large files.

This integration can be done in the Egress task pane in Microsoft Outlook:

Expand the below sections to learn more:

  • In the task pane, the Protection levels drop-down menu allows you to select the most appropriate encryption option for the information you send. Hover over each option to view a full description.

    The available Protection levels are:

    • Unprotected
    • Encrypted

  • Large File Transfer (LFT) can be used when you want to share large files with recipients in an efficient and secure way. Uploading large files as a standard email attachment can be time-consuming and result in transmission failures if the files are too large.

    Note:Please follow all instructions in the task pane and ensure you do not click away or send your email before all LFT files have been successfully uploaded.

    When required, Large File Transfer (LFT) can be enabled in two ways:

    • Directly uploading attachments into the LFT box in the task pane.
    • Attaching files as normal to the email you are composing and then enabling LFT in the task pane. When enabled, the attachments will be automatically transferred to LFT.

  • Why has my LFT upload failed?

    Sometimes, upload failures can occur due to connection issues. Try uploading again, but if the problem persists, please contact Egress Support.

    Why have my existing email attachments been transferred to LFT?

    When you enable LFT, attachments added to emails as normal will be automatically transferred to LFT. You cannot have LFT uploads and normal attachments in one email.

    When should I use LFT?

    Use LFT when you need to securely and efficiently send large files that cannot be effectively sent using standard email attachment methods.

    Why does my LFT upload fail when I click away from the email?

    You must ensure you do not click away from the email or task pane until an upload is complete. Otherwise, the upload will fail.

articles.name: Web Add-In User Experience Guides
articles.title: Web Add-In User Experience Guides
articles.body:
The Microsoft Outlook add-in gives you access to Protect functionality in your email application. Your organization has enabled this add-in to ensure the safe and correct data is sent through email.

The experience of using the Microsoft Outlook add-in varies depending on whether you use it on Windows, Mac, or Outlook on the web (OWA). Expand the relevant section below to learn how to use your Microsoft Outlook add-in.

  • Recipient Advice

    As you compose an email and add recipients, you will be provided with live advice. Recipients will be categorized according to the level of risk they present. You can click the X icons to remove recipients who present higher risks.

    Data Loss Prevention Prompts

    If you attempt to send an email that contains sensitive information without selecting an appropriate level of encryption, a pop-up window will appear when you click Send.

    In the pop-up window, select a level of encryption before attempting to resend the email. If you don't make the necessary changes to an email, you will receive another prompt informing you that the email cannot be sent.

    Sensitive information that can trigger Data Loss Prevention prompts include:

    1. Financial information
    2. IP addresses
    3. Legal data
    4. HR data
    5. Information found within email attachments

  • Signing In or Out

    When composing an email, click the three dots icon in the top-right corner of the Microsoft Outlook menu bar. Click Egress for Outlook. The Egress task pane opens.

    The task pane is displayed on the right side of the New Email window. By default, the email ID of the inbox you are currently using will be used as your Egress ID.

    To sign in:

    1. Enter your Egress ID.
    2. Click Continue.
    3. Enter your Password.
    4. Click Login.

    To sign out:

    1. Open the Egress task pane.
    2. Click the gear icon.
    3. Click Logout.

    Protection Labels

    The drop-down menu in the task pane can be used to select the appropriate level of encryption and security for your email content and recipients.

    Recipient Advice

    As you compose an email and add recipients, you will be provided with live advice. Recipients will be categorized according to the level of risk they present. You can click the X icons to remove recipients who present higher risks.

    Data Loss Prevention Prompts

    If you attempt to send an email that contains sensitive information without selecting an appropriate level of encryption, a pop-up window will appear when you click Send.

    In the pop-up window, select a level of encryption before attempting to resend the email. If you don't make the necessary changes to an email, you will receive another prompt informing you that the email cannot be sent.

    Sensitive information that can trigger Data Loss Prevention prompts include:

    • Financial information
    • IP addresses
    • Legal data
    • HR data
    • Information found within email attachments

  • Signing In or Out

    When composing an email, click the Egress button on the top ribbon to view the Egress task pane:

    To sign in:

    1. Enter your Egress ID.
    2. Click Continue.
    3. Enter your Password.
    4. Click Login.

    To sign out:

    1. Open the Egress task pane.
    2. Click the gear icon.
    3. Click Logout.

    Protection Labels

    The drop-down menu in the task pane can be used to select the appropriate level of encryption and security for your email content and recipients.

    Recipient Advice

    As you compose an email and add recipients, you will be provided with live advice. Recipients will be categorized according to the level of risk they present. You can click the X icons to remove recipients who present higher risks.

    Data Loss Prevention Prompts

    If you attempt to send an email that contains sensitive information without selecting an appropriate level of encryption, a pop-up window will appear when you click Send.

    In the pop-up window, select a level of encryption before attempting to resend the email. If you don't make the necessary changes to an email, you will receive another prompt informing you that the email cannot be sent.

    Sensitive information that can trigger Data Loss Prevention prompts include:

    1. Financial information
    2. IP addresses
    3. Legal data
    4. HR data
    5. Information found within email attachments

articles.name: Web Add-In
articles.title: Web Add-In
articles.body:
There are now two Microsoft Outlook add-ins (COM and Web add-in). When should I use each one?

There are two add-ins for Microsoft Outlook that can be used independently or in conjunction to provide optimal user experience and security coverage. Both add-ins are centrally managed and can be deployed to use the same policy configuration.

To understand when to use each add-in, see the Outlook Add-Ins - COM vs Web Add-In article.

Which version of Microsoft Outlook should I use?

This answer is entirely up to your organization. We support all versions of Microsoft Outlook as we offer a Web and COM add-in.

How long will there be support for Classic Outlook and the COM add-in?

Microsoft has confirmed that Support for Classic Outlook and COM will continue until 2029. We will also continue to support this until then.

When I send emails, I find that some of my emails are stuck in my Drafts folder.

Unfortunately, this is a known issue when you click away too quickly while the email is being processed. We have raised this with Microsoft to fix it. In the meantime, we have a workaround available for your users. For full details about the workaround, see the Web Add-In: On Send Feature article.

Do I need to switch to the New Outlook and the web add-in to use Microsoft Copilot?

Microsoft has announced support for Copilot in Classic Outlook in their recent roadmap updates, as shown in the Microsoft 365 Roadmap - See What's Coming | Microsoft 365 article. You can find further Microsoft 365 requirements in the Microsoft Copilot for Microsoft 365 requirements | Microsoft Learn article.

Are there any prerequisites for using the new Web add-in?

Customers wanting to use this must be native Microsoft 365 only, with no on-premise services.

The admin must have access to the following:

  • Office JS Manifest
  • Administrative rights to the Microsoft 365 admin portal
  • Optional: Microsoft 365 or Azure AD group to assign Office JS to a user group
  • Outlook JavaScript API requirement set 1.8 or later
Note:This add-in is not available for Exchange on-premise.

Deployment is done via the Microsoft 365 admin portal as an integrated app. This deployment will need to be performed as a one-off task by a Microsoft 365 admin with one of the below roles:

  • Global Administrator
  • Exchange Administrator combined with one of either Cloud App Admin, App Admin, or Privileged Role Admin

articles.name: Web Add-In - Deployment Guide for Protect
articles.title: Web Add-In - Deployment Guide for Protect
articles.body:
This guide explains how to deploy the web add-in for your Microsoft 365 users. This solution enhances your organization's security by providing powerful encryption services and delivering real-time guidance when sending emails. It ensures consistent protection throughout your organization, as the add-in will be deployed to all supported devices, including Outlook Web Access (OWA), Mac, and Windows.

Prerequisites

Before you get started, please ensure you have the following:

  • Global admin rights to your organization's Microsoft 365 admin portal
  • Microsoft Outlook JavaScript (JS) API requirement set 1.8 or later
  • A gateway must be provisioned for all Web add-in deployments
  • We recommend that the gateway be configured with a moderation mailbox. See the Gateway Configuration article for more details.
  • Optional: Microsoft 365 or Azure AD group to assign Office JS to a user group

Deployment Steps

  1. Log in to your Microsoft 365 admin portal. 
  2. Navigate to Settings > Integrated apps > Add-ins.

  3. Select I have a URL for the manifest file and paste the URL for the Microsoft add-in manifest file into the field.
    • UK Manifest: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-uk-manifest.xml
    • US Manifest: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-us-manifest.xml
    • EU Manifest: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-eu-manifest.xml
    • AU Manifest: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-au-manifest.xml
  4. Once you select Upload, you will need to select who you want to deploy the application to and how you want to deploy it:
    • Assign Users: Select Specific users/groups and add the chosen users or groups.
    • Deployment Method: Select Optional.
  5. Click Deploy.
  6. A green tick will display when the add-in is deployed. It may take up to 12 hours before the application appears for users.

Allowlisting

To allow the proper functioning of our services, ensure the following URLs are listed on your firewall or proxy:

  • switch.egress.com
  • gc.egress.com

Use the correct URLs for your region:

  • uk.intelligence.egress.com
  • uk.kes.knowbe4.com
  • us.intelligence.egress.com
  • us.kes.knowbe4.com
  • eu.intelligence.egress.com
  • eu.kes.knowbe4.com
  • au.intelligence.egress.com
  • au.kes.knowbe4.com

articles.name: Web Add-In Change Log
articles.title: Web Add-In Change Log
articles.body:
Release Date Description
July 2025

July 2025 - We’ve updated the web add-in infrastructure to introduce a KnowBe4 rebrand and a timeout functionality.

  • New Customers: New customers who have used the Prevent Deployment Center will automatically receive the updated interface and timeout functionality. 
  • Existing Legacy Prevent Customers: A migration project will launch soon. If you want early access, update your web add-in manifest files using your regional link below.
    • US: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-us-manifest.xml 
    • UK: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-uk-manifest.xml 
    • AU: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-au-manifest.xml 
    • EU: https://www.knowbe4.com/hubfs/prod-eu-manifest.xml
  • Timeout Functionality: The web add-in will now default to using the gateway for analysis when performance delays are encountered. This functionality requires existing customers to have a configured Prevent gateway in place. For full details about the Legacy Prevent gateway configuration, see our Prevent - Gateway Configuration article.
Release Date Description
December 2024

December 4, 2024 - We're pleased to announce the latest update to the Egress Web Add-in, which includes the following performance improvements:

  • Resolved an issue where users were experiencing intermittent blank prompts when attempting to send emails.
  • Resolved an issue with the Data Loss Prevention prompt, which displayed malformed category values.
September 2024

September 6, 2024—The web add-in has had a makeover, including functionality changes, to improve your end-user experience. The following changes have been made depending on whether you are a Prevent and/or Protect customer.

Prevent Experience:

  • The shield icon has been removed - email advice is displayed in the task pane and color-coded based on the detected risk.
  • If the task pane is open and a risk is found when composing an email, the red or orange risk section will automatically expand to display risk details.

Protect Experience:

  • Encryption
    • Encryption labels have been renamed to Protection Levels.
  • Large File Transfer (LFT)
    • This can be enabled using a toggle in the task pane.
    • If an end-user has already added attachments to an email and then enables LFT, those attachments will be automatically transferred to LFT.

articles.name: Protect - User Resources
articles.title: Protect - User Resources
articles.body:
Note: This article has recently been added to our Knowledge Base. Thank you for your patience as we continue to make improvements.

Welcome to the user resource page!

High-Level Overview

Check out this short video on why sending emails securely via Protect is important.

Getting Started with Protect Resources

  • How to Create a New Secure Email Using the Secure Message Portal
  • Protect User Guide (Web Add-In)
  • Protect User Guide (COM Add-In)
  • Web Access - How to Approve or Deny Access Requests

articles.name: Protect Resource Hub
articles.title: Protect Resource Hub
articles.body:
Welcome to the Protect Resource Hub. We hope to make your onboarding experience as smooth as possible by providing you with the necessary resources for both admins and end users:

  • Admins: Guides to assist with the deployment process of Protect.
  • End Users: Bite-sized videos and user guides to share with users to help them understand and maximize the functionalities of Protect.

articles.name: COM Add-In Registry Keys
articles.title: COM Add-In Registry Keys
articles.body:
If, for some reason, your organization is not able to upgrade to v23.03 or later, follow the steps below to add the registry keys to your users' profiles manually:

Name Value Type Location
EgressEmailProtection 1 String [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\office\16.0\outlook\Resiliency\AddinList]
LoadBehavior 3 DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection]
EgressEmailProtection 1 DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\DoNotDisableAddinList]
EgressEmailProtection\dtype 0 DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]
EgressEmailProtection 967a844d DWORD [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]

If the COM add-in has been previously disabled for this user, then this information is stored in the registry and will prevent admins from re-enabling the COM add-in. The following keys need to be deleted:

  • [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\DisabledItems]
  • [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\CrashingAddinList]

articles.name: Microsoft Outlook Desktop Sync Interval
articles.title: Microsoft Outlook Desktop Sync Interval
articles.body:
The Microsoft Outlook add-in uses the Outlook OnSend feature, which can delay mail processing for up to 60 seconds. The default upload interval for OnSend is 15 seconds, with a maximum of 60 seconds.

The registry key below can be used to override this, such as to an interval of one second up to a maximum of five seconds. This feature ensures that users never wait more than the specified maximum amount of time for a sync to occur.

The following .reg file configures an upload interval of one second with a fivesecond maximum. The .reg file can be found here.

articles.name: Protect - One-Click Access
articles.title: Protect - One-Click Access
articles.body:
One-click access reduces friction for recipients of Secure Emails by allowing them to view the email content without needing to create an account or authenticate. Recipients will receive a notification email containing a unique access link, allowing them to view the email using the Secure Message Portal.

One-click access is not the recommended setup for optimal security practices. Anyone who gains access to the unique access link can view the email content. One-click access can only be configured by a KnowBe4 employee, so contact our support team to enable this feature.

Note: Recipients will have One-click Access to an email for 7 days. After this period expires, they will need to sign in or create an account to continue accessing the content.

Requirements

The requirements needed for this feature are listed below:

  • Gateway
  • Up-to-date Protect policies
  • Risk sign-off by customer

Workflow

The workflow of this feature is explained below:

  1. A secure email is sent.

  2. Selected recipients receive a notification email containing a unique access link.

  3. Upon clicking the Open Secure Email button, the recipient is taken to the secure email.

  4. When a recipient accesses the email, an entry in the Secure Email Audit Events is created, showing who and when the email was accessed.

  5. The sender of the secure email has full access controls and can easily revoke access when required.

articles.name: Unable to See Replies to Secure Emails
articles.title: Unable to See Replies to Secure Emails
articles.body:
Sometimes, users may reply to a secure email notification rather than the secure email itself. In this case, when the reply is opened within Microsoft Outlook, it will automatically decrypt the .switch file, which hides the reply behind it.

If you select the X icon in the right-hand corner of the secure email, as shown below, then it should display the unencrypted reply.

articles.name: Gathering Screenshots or an Export of Registry Keys
articles.title: Gathering Screenshots or an Export of Registry Keys
articles.body:
Sometimes, the support team may ask for screenshots or an export of your registry keys to continue troubleshooting issues with the Microsoft Outlook add-in.

Screenshot of Registry Keys

To gather these screenshots, please follow the instructions below:

  1. Open the Registry Editor by pressing the Windows or Command + R keys.
  2. Type "regedit" and select OK to open the Registry Editor.
  3. From here, browse to the following three locations and take screenshots of each location. The locations are:
    • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Egress\Switch
    • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch
    • HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection
  4. Reply to our support team on your ticket, including the screenshots.

Export of Registry Keys

To gather the export of your registry keys, follow the instructions below:

  1. Open the Registry Editor by pressing the Windows or Command + R keys.
  2. Type "regedit" and select OK to open the Registry Editor.
  3. Select File and then Export.
  4. On the window that pops up, you can specify the location of the registry keys you would like to export or export all of your registry keys. If you want to narrow down to what we usually need to see, these are below, but our support team will let you know if we need any additional locations:
    • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Egress\Switch
    • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch
    • HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection
  5. Reply to your support engineer on your ticket, including any export files.

articles.name: Protect - Sent Packages
articles.title: Protect - Sent Packages
articles.body:
Sending, accessing, and managing your secure emails can be done using Sent Packages. You can access this through the Sent Packages button in your main Microsoft Outlook ribbon. A browser will open, allowing you to view the secure emails you have shared.

Selecting an email entry opens a pop-up window which will display the following information:

  • Details
    • View email details as well as edit the Subject, Classification, Tags, Status, Time Restrictions, and Recipients.
    • An email can be revoked by clicking the Status drop-down menu and selecting Revoke.
  • Offline Access
    • Provide the recipient with a password to access the email offline. Select Show Passwords to display passwords for full and restricted access.
    • Once a password has been provided to a recipient, you will not be able to revoke the email or prevent access.
  • Package Contents
    • View the attributes of the email and any attachments.
  • Delivery Reports
    • View when a user has first and last accessed the email.
  • Audit Events
    • View all the events and activities related to the email details, such as access attempts and status changes.

To apply any changes you have made in this pop-up, ensure you click Save Changes.

articles.name: FAQs: New Microsoft Outlook
articles.title: FAQs: New Microsoft Outlook
articles.body:
In this article, you can find frequently asked questions about the new Microsoft Outlook update. If you have additional questions that this article doesn’t include, please submit a ticket to our support team.

What is the new Microsoft Outlook?

In May 2022, Microsoft introduced the preview mode for the new Outlook for Windows. As of August 2024, the new Microsoft Outlook for Windows became generally available for commercial customers. This feature allowed users to opt in to use the new Microsoft Outlook.

Microsoft has stated that the next phase will be to opt out of using the new Outlook, making the new Outlook the default. There are no confirmed dates for this next phase, but Microsoft has stated that the classic Outlook experience will be available until its supported timeline, which is currently until 2029.

For more information on the new Outlook, see Microsoft's Getting started with the new Outlook for Windows article.

Does this affect my Microsoft Outlook add-ins?

The new Outlook will not support tadd-ins built with Microsoft's COM architecture, and many software vendors, including Protect, are building new Outlook add-ins using Microsoft's new Office.js architecture.

What does this mean for my Add-In for Outlook?

Protect will continue to develop and support our COM add-in for Microsoft Outlook while Microsoft still supports it, and we have not announced end-of-support or end-of-life.

Protect also offers a new OWA add-in for customers who want to upgrade to the early release of the new Microsoft Outlook or non-Windows users who need the Protect add-in. Below is a comparison between the Microsoft Outlook add-in (COM) and the Web add-in for the new Microsoft Outlook, OWA, or Mac.

Feature Microsoft Outlook Add-in (COM) Microsoft Outlook Add-in (Web)
Available for All users (Free/licensed) Licensed customers 50 employees
Supported Outlook Microsoft Outlook for Windows 2016/2019/Pro Plus/Office 365 Office 365 for Windows, Outlook Web Access, Outlook for Mac
Protect Gateway Encryption Yes Yes
Protect Local Encryption Yes No
Protect Large File Transfer Yes Yes, but not supported for Classic Outlook
Prevent Yes Yes
Prevent DLP Yes Yes

For information on how to obtain the latest version of both add-ins, visit our downloads page.

If you upgrade to the new Microsoft Outlook, COM-based add-ins will not be available. This upgrade includes the COM add-in. For information on how to prevent users from manually upgrading Microsoft Outlook, see the Disable Upgrade to New Outlook for Windows article.

If I'm a free user of Protect, what does this upgrade mean for me?

If you are currently a free Protect email encryption user and use the COM add-in to send and open secure emails, upgrading to the new Microsoft Outlook means that you will need to use our Secure Message Portal to open and access secure emails.

articles.name: New Outlook for Windows
articles.title: New Outlook for Windows
articles.body:
Microsoft has released the newest version of Microsoft Outlook: New Outlook for Windows. This version is generally available to commercial users, and users can opt-in to try the new experience:

Admins should be aware that COM add-ins are not supported in the New Outlook for Windows. As a result, you will not be able to use our COM add-in. For further information, see Microsoft's Outlook Add-Ins Overview article.

There are two options admins can take. These are:

  1. Hide the "Try the new Outlook" button. If you do not want users to be able to install the new Outlook, hide the button using the following registry key:
    1. HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Options\General
    2. DWORD with the name HideNewOutlookToggle and its value set to 1.
  2. Download our Web add-in. The Web add-in is fully supported if you want to use the new Outlook.

articles.name: Web Add-In Error - "Prevent requires access to local storage"
articles.title: Web Add-In Error - "Prevent requires access to local storage"
articles.body:
The web add-in requires local storage to store sign-in information for users, allowing them to stay signed in. Users may see errors regarding access to local storage if said access is blocked or restricted.

The most common reason for this error is when an organization uses Microsoft Outlook on the web (OWA), but users have cookies set to Blocked on their internet browsers.

This error can be resolved by enabling cookies in your users' browser with the following steps below:

  1. In your browser, navigate to Settings > Privacy and Security. Most web browsers offer this option, where you can control cookie preferences.
  2. You will need to allow sites to save and read cookie data and allow the use of third-party cookies.

If you do not want to enable cookies for all sites, you can add exceptions to resolve this specifically for the Web add-in. To do this, add an exception for https://[*.]uk.office.egress.com:443.

articles.name: Emails Not Previewing Correctly in the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
articles.title: Emails Not Previewing Correctly in the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
articles.body:
Sometimes, emails may not be decrypted when using our Microsoft Outlook add-in. This issue is most often caused by the add-in inability to detect that an email requires decryption due to the content of the notification being modified.

Encrypted emails are detected by reading the body of a message and searching for signs of an encrypted email within the notification. The add-in also searches for .switch files added to a message.

We recommend trying the following troubleshooting steps:

  1. Ensure you can open the .switch file if one is attached to the email. If you can open the attachment, the email has been received correctly.
  2. Open Registry Editor and navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Egress\Switch
    1. Right-click in a blank space, click New, then select DWORD.
    2. Set the name to DEMTextDetection and the value to 0.
    3. Do the same steps here: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Egress\Switch
    4. Restart Microsoft Outlook and check if the issue is resolved.

articles.name: How to Refresh Policies in the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
articles.title: How to Refresh Policies in the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
articles.body:
Policies are used to determine the behavior of the Microsoft Outlook COM add-in. When changes are made to your policies, you must refresh the policies in your Microsoft Outlook COM add-in.

To do this, follow the instructions below:

  1. Open the File menu in Microsoft Outlook.
  2. Select Egress.
  3. Ensure you are signed in and select Refresh Policies.
  4. Once you've done this, restart Microsoft Outlook. You will then have the latest version of your organization's policies, including any changes or updates.

articles.name: Protect - Emails Automatically Being Encrypted
articles.title: Protect - Emails Automatically Being Encrypted
articles.body:
If you are seeing emails automatically being encrypted without selecting encryption, there can be two reasons for this.

Replying to an Encrypted Email

You are replying to an encrypted email. If the email you are replying to or forwarding is a secure email, even if you select to send unencrypted, it will still be sent securely.

Default Microsoft Outlook Add-In Settings

By default, the Microsoft Outlook add-In automatically encrypts emails with attachments over 10MB. This threshold can be customized using a registry key.

Note:Depending on your permission settings, you may need to request these changes from your IT department.

To change the 10 MB auto encrypt feature:

  1. Open Regedit. To do this, select the Start button. In the Start Menu, in either the Run or Search box, type "regedit" and press Enter or Return.
  2. Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Egress\Switch and HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch.
  3. Right-click in the white space on the right-hand side of Regedit, underneath (Default), and create a DWORD called “LargeFileMinKB”.
  4. When adding the Value, change the “Base” to “Decimal” to add the size you would like to change to in bytes. For example, 30000 Decimal will be just under 30 MB.

articles.name: How to See What Add-In Versions Are Being Used in Your Business Account
articles.title: How to See What Add-In Versions Are Being Used in Your Business Account
articles.body:
If you are an admin and want to check what versions your users are currently using within your business account, please follow the instructions below:

  1. Please sign into your admin account here: https://switch.egress.com/.
  2. Navigate to User Management on the left-hand side of the screen.
  3. At the bottom of the user list, you will see a link called Download as CSV.
  4. This link will download a CSV file of a list of your users and information about their account.
  5. Under the Full Client Version column, any users that have signed into the client within the last three months will be displayed with the version they used to sign in.

articles.name: How to Disable or Remove the Microsoft Outlook Add-In for Your Organization
articles.title: How to Disable or Remove the Microsoft Outlook Add-In for Your Organization
articles.body:
To disable but not remove the Microsoft Outlook add-in, follow the steps below:

  1. Open Microsoft Outlook.
  2. Navigate to File > Options > Add-ins.
  3. At the bottom of the window under Manage, ensure the COM Add-ins option is selected and select Go.
  4. Unselect the box next to Egress and select OK.
  5. Close down Microsoft Outlook. The add-in should now be disabled.

To remove the Microsoft Outlook add-in, follow the steps below:

  1. Ensure Microsoft Outlook is closed.
  2. On your device, navigate to Add or Remove Programs.
  3. Under Apps and Features, scroll down to Egress.
  4. Select Egress and then Uninstall.
  5. Follow the steps from the uninstaller.

articles.name: How to Disable the Protect Gateway
articles.title: How to Disable the Protect Gateway
articles.body:
This article provides a comprehensive guide on disabling Protect, including the necessary steps to modify Microsoft 365 settings, on-premise Exchange configurations, and other secure email gateways. Whether you're transitioning to a different email security solution or need to disable Protect temporarily, this step-by-step guide will walk you through the process, ensuring a smooth and secure transition for your organization's email communications.

To disable Protect, you will first need to complete the following steps:

  • Disable any mail flow rules within Microsoft 365 and any other secure email gateway
  • Disable the Transport Agent if used in combination with on-premise Microsoft Exchange
  • Remove any Protect send and receive connectors in Microsoft 365 or on-premise Exchange
  • Remove any Protect connectors or accepted relays at any other secure email gateway

If you wish to continue using the Microsoft Outlook add-in without the Gateway, you should remove the following registry keys which will have been used to enable Gateway mode:

  • [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Egress\Switch] "Forcegatewaymode" "Gatewayaddress" "MinimumSizeKB"
  • [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Egress\Switch] "Forcegatewaymode" "Gatewayaddress" "MinimumSizeKB"

If you do not wish to continue using our plug-in, you should also remove this. At the end of your contract, any customized policies, including branding, will be reverted to the default configuration.

articles.name: Upgrading the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
articles.title: Upgrading the Microsoft Outlook Add-In
articles.body:
This article provides guidance on upgrading the Microsoft Outlook add-In to the latest version.

Manual Desktop Installation

  • The installation process is a simple click-through installer delivered in an .exe package.
  • To run the installer, you must have admin privileges on the target machine. Local admin rights are sufficient.

Silent Install

An MSI package that can be deployed silently via a command line or by using deployment tools such as SCCM.

Command Line (msiexec)

The default command for installing the MSI via a command line is:

  • msiexec /i "EgressEmailProtection.msi"

The default command for uninstalling is:

  • msiexec /x "EgressEmailProtection.msi"

You can add other parameters, such as /quiet, as required.

Command Line Switches

The MSI has several switches that can be set with the "msiexec" command to enable or disable certain features.

Flag Function Values Default Value
BYPASSOUTLOOKCHECK Bypass checking whether MS Outlook is open for fresh installs only and not upgrades. If upgrading from 21.06, this flag will work. Note: This switch does not apply to removing older versions, and Outlook must be closed in that scenario. Set these properties to something other than white space, such as "1", in order to bypass checks <<white-space>>
INSTALLADDINKEYS Installs add-in keys (above) for all users on the machine Note: Users should use this key with the value “None” when installing Citrix.

"AllUsers"

"CurrentUser"

"None"

 "AllUsers"

Msiexec Install Command

Installing the Microsoft Outlook add-in requires the below install command:

  • msiexec /i "EgressEmailProtection.msi" /quiet

Deployment Tools

Deployment tools such as Microsoft SCCM or Tivoli can be used to deploy the Outlook client to a large group of users in a controlled way.

Group Policy Deployment

To deploy the MSI package via group policy, add or update the package within the Computer Configuration section within the group policy by following the steps below:

Note: It is very important that the path to the MSI file is not local or run through a network drive. Instead, it should be through a network share, accessible from everywhere in your network and everyone should have at least Read permissions.

  1. Load the Group Policy Management console.

  2. Right-click Group Policy Objects and select New.

  3. Open the group policy object editor.
  4. Expand Computer Configuration Software Settings.

  5. Right-click Software Settings and select Software Installation New Package…

  6. Point to the EgressEmailProtection.msi file.
  7. Under Deployment Method, select Advanced. If you choose another option, you won't be able to apply an MST if required.
  8. Add a name for the package for easy identification.

Once the group policy object is created, you will need to apply it to the relevant AD groups so that it is installed on user machines.

ADMX Template

The preferred method for deploying the Microsoft Outlook client registry keys is by utilizing ADMX templates within a Group Policy. These template files contain various user-level registry settings that control the behavior of the Microsoft Outlook desktop client.

Ensure that the ADMX template files have been placed in the relevant location. Typically, this is:

  • ADMX: C:\Windows\PolicyDefinitions
  • ADML: C:\Windows\PolicyDefinitions\en-us

The Microsoft Outlook client is highly configurable and different configurations not listed above can be controlled by command line switches and/or registry settings. As well as user settings, the client ADMX templates can apply machine-based policies such as the Gateway settings or SSO configuration.

VDI Installation or Deploying in Hidden Mode

This section will cover the work involved in environments such as:

  • Microsoft RDS
  • Citrix
  • General hot-desk or terminal server environments

If you need to deploy to specific users in any of the above environments, you will need to deploy the add-in in a hidden state by default and then enable it using user-level registry keys. This action is common for organizations that haven’t purchased a site-wide license where users do not have their own dedicated physical machines.

Authentication Prerequisites

A token is stored within the local data. This token is refreshed daily to keep the user signed in. In doing so, the following folder paths must be persistent. The folder will depend on the environment you are configured to:

  • AppData\Local\egress\6\switch.egress.com
  • AppData\Local\egress\6\us1.esi.egress.com
  • AppData\Local\egress\6\eu1.esi.egress.com
  • For on-premise or separate hosted ESIs, replace the respective end folder with the hostname

If users roam between multiple servers, an additional registry key must be applied to ensure they remain logged in when switching between them. This requirement is due to the login token is device-specific. If a user switches from Server A and then to Server B, they will be required to log in again.

To prevent this issue, the following registry key must be applied.

Location:

  • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \Software \Egress\Switch
  • HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE \Software\Wow6432node\Egress\Switch

Registry Key:

  • REG_SZ (String) with the name: DeviceID
  • Value: profile

Not all users may require the Microsoft Outlook add-in. For some users, the add-in must be installed in the disabled format and then targeted for specific users.

Msiexec Install

Install can be performed by via GPO, SCCM, or other deployment tools.

Msiexec Installed in Hidden Mode

Install with the following Command:

  • msiexec /i "EgressEmailProtection.msi" /quiet INSTALLADDINKEYS='None'

Show Add-In for Targeted Users

To show the plugin for specific users, the following registry keys are required:

  • [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection]
  • "LoadBehavior"=dword:00000003
  • "Manifest"=' file:///C:\Program Files (x86)\Egress Email Protection\EmailProtection.vsto|vstolocal'

If GPO is required for registry key push out, please follow the guidance below for GPO only install from step two onwards.

GPO Only Install

To install for GPO, follow the steps below:

  1. Create a new GPO with the new Microsoft Outlook client and add the MST to the modification tab. This action will install the add-in in the disabled format.

  2. Ensure the ADMX templates have been added. Once the templates are in place, right-click the group policy and select Edit. Follow this path: User Configuration Administrative Templates Egress Settings.

  3. A list of policy options will be displayed in this folder.

  4. In most cases, to enable the client for certain users, it is recommended you configure each of the following options and set their actions as below:

    • Email Resiliency - To force Microsoft Outlook to always load the Microsoft Outlook add-in and prevent users from disabling it, the value should be set to 1.

    • Load Behavior Add-in - This setting will load and enable the Microsoft Outlook add-in. It should be set to 3.

    • Manifest Outlook Add-in - Loads the Microsoft Outlook add-in manifest file. This setting should be set to:
      • file///C:\Program Files (x86)\Egress Email Protection\EmailProtection.vsto|vstolocal

If there is a mixture of 32-bit and 64-bit machines, use WMI filtering or Item-Level Targeting to apply the correct path based on the OS bitness.

Once the appropriate policy definitions have been defined, ensure that your GPO is saved, linked to the right domain, and applied to the relevant AD security group.

FAQs

The most common questions or issues about upgrading the Microsoft Outlook add-in are addressed below.

  1. The naming convention has been updated from Egress.Switch to EgressEmailProtection for where the LoadBehavior & Manifest keys reside:
    1. HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection
    2. HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection
  2. To ensure the plugin stays enabled, the following keys should be pushed out by the admin:
    • EgressEmailProtection
      • Value: 1
      • Type: String
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\office\16.0\outlook\Resiliency\AddinList]
    • LoadBehavior
      • Value: 3
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\Outlook\Addins\EgressEmailProtection]
    • EgressEmailProtection
      • Value: 1
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\DoNotDisableAddinList]
    • EgressEmailProtection\dtype
      • Value: 0
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]
    • EgressEmailProtection
      • Value: 967a844d
      • Type: DWORD
      • Location: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\16.0\Outlook\Resiliency\NotificationReminderAddinData]

articles.name: What Languages Does the Outlook Add-In Support?
articles.title: What Languages Does the Outlook Add-In Support?
articles.body:
The Microsoft Outlook add-in's supported languages are:

  • Dutch
  • French
  • Italian
  • Spanish
  • German
  • Portuguese
  • Norwegian
  • Hungarian

Languages using double-byte characters are not currently supported.

articles.name: Incompatible Version of Microsoft Outlook Installed Error
articles.title: Incompatible Version of Microsoft Outlook Installed Error
articles.body:
Pre-installed Microsoft Store apps of Outlook may cause issues when installing the Outlook add-in. This installation may result in a similar error as seen in the screenshot below:

To remove the pre-installed Microsoft Store version of Office, run the script below in PowerShell:

Get-AppxPackage -name “Microsoft.Office.Desktop” | Remove-AppxPackage
Get-AppxProvisionedPackage -online | %{if ($_.packagename -match "Microsoft.Office.Desktop") {$_ | Remove-AppxProvisionedPackage -AllUsers}}

Ensure no registry keys from the older versions are still in place by following the steps below:

  1. Open up Regedit.
  2. Locate to HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\TypeLib\{00062FFF-0000-0000-C000-000000000046}.
  3. Make a backup of this registry location before making any changes.
  4. Delete the version keys for any version of Microsoft Outlook that is not installed on the machine based on the version table provided below.
Outlook Version Version Number
Outlook 2007 9.3
Outlook 2010 9.4
Outlook 2013 9.5
Outlook 2016 9.6
Outlook 2019 9.7

articles.name: Do I need to download software to use Egress?
articles.title: Do I need to download software to use Egress?
articles.body:
There is no obligation to download our software, Egress Protect services are available online for free through the Egress Secure Message Portal.

 

If you think you may need software, please visit our website for more information as well as available downloads. We also have mobile apps available for iOS and Android.

articles.name: ADFS "Failed Authentication" - Error Message
articles.title: ADFS "Failed Authentication" - Error Message
articles.body:
If you are using ADFS for single sign-on (SSO), you may receive the following error when opening Microsoft Outlook:

Failed authentication. The server was unable to process the request due to an internal error. For more information about the error, either turn on IncludeExceptionDetaillnFaults (either from ServiceBehaviorAttribute or from the <serviceDebug>configuration behavior) on the server in order to send the exception information back to the client, or turn on tracing as per the Microsoft .NET Framework SDK documentation and inspect the server trace logs.

Resolution

If you are seeing this error, there is likely an issue with the ADFS server. It would be advised to check the IIS services and, if necessary, reboot the server.

For further information, please consult the official Microsoft support advice.

articles.name: How Large Can Secure Email Attachments Be?
articles.title: How Large Can Secure Email Attachments Be?
articles.body:
If you use the Secure Message Portal, you can send secure emails only up to 50 MB. This limit applies to both free and paid users.

If you try to upload files that add up to more than 50 MB, you will see an error message like this:

articles.name: Why Recipients Have to Request Access to Open Secure Emails Sent by Me
articles.title: Why Recipients Have to Request Access to Open Secure Emails Sent by Me
articles.body:
When sending secure emails to your recipients, some recipients will have to request access before they can open them.

This issue is usually caused by the recipient signing in with a different email address than the one you originally sent to.

This issue can take place in the following scenarios:

  1. The email is forwarded to the recipient from another user
  2. The recipient having more than one email address
  3. The email is sent to a group mailbox, and the user is signed in with their ID

Please ensure that the recipient is signing in with the same email address to which you sent the secure email.

You can see the exact email addresses you originally sent your secure email by signing in to the Switch login page and clicking Sent Packages on the left side of the screen. If you select the secure email in question, you will see a full access list of recipients with allowed email addresses.
